channel.title: Is there a easy way to write this code?[Delta]
channel.description: [code]if(playerEquipment[playerHat] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerWeapon] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerShield] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerCape] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerAmulet] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerChest] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerLegs] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerHands] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerFeet] = -1 && playerEquipment[playerArrows] = -1){ [/code] Trying to make it where you can't have anything equip to enter the place, so i got everything ready but I get a error with this code which states "bad operand types for binary operator '&&'" and had this error "incompatible types" How do I write this code?

item.source: Is there a easy way to write this code?[Delta]

item.title: Is there a easy way to write this code?[Delta]
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“deathschaos9, post:4, topic:518550”]In Java, = is an assignment operator and == is an equality/conditional operator.

I’m very happy to see someone wanting to learn, you can find more information about Java operators here.

And because I’m bored:

[code=Java]
public class Example {

static int varA = 0; // Initialization/Assignment
static int varB;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    varB = varA; // Assignment
    if (varA == varB) // Equality operator "if varA is equal to varB"
        System.out.println("varA and varB are equal.");
}

}[/code]
The comments in that simple program show the difference between the two operators.[/quote]
Thank you! This community needs more activity between both sides; learners and helpers.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a easy way to write this code?[Delta]

item.title: Is there a easy way to write this code?[Delta]
item.dc:creator: @deathschaos9 DeathsChaos9
item.description:
@deathschaos9 wrote:

In Java, = is an assignment operator and == is an equality/conditional operator.

I’m very happy to see someone wanting to learn, you can find more information about Java operators here.

And because I’m bored:

[code=Java]
public class Example {

static int varA = 0; // Initialization/Assignment
static int varB;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    varB = varA; // Assignment
    if (varA == varB) // Equality operator "if varA is equal to varB"
        System.out.println("varA and varB are equal.");
}

}[/code]
The comments in that simple program show the difference between the two operators.
